text: ANNOUNCEMENT AND REPORT
label: HH1

text: CONCERNING
label: TITLE

text: ADVANCE PRICING AGREEMENTS
label: HH1

text: March 31, 2003
label: BODY

text: This Announcement is issued pursuant to § 521(b) of Pub. L. 106-170, the Ticket to Work and
label: BODY

text: Work Incentives Improvement Act of 1999, requiring that the Secretary of the Treasury annually
label: BODY

text: report to the public concerning Advance Pricing Agreements (APAs) and the APA Program.
label: BODY

text: The first report covered calendar years 1991 through 1999.  Subsequent reports covered calendar
label: BODY

text: years 2000 and 2001.  This fourth report describes the experience of the APA Program during
label: BODY

text: calendar year 2002 consistent with the mandate of § 521(b).  This document does not provide
label: BODY

text: guidance regarding the application of the arm’s length standard; rather, it reports on the structure
label: BODY

text: and activities of the APA program.
label: BODY

text: Mindy Piatoff
label: BODY

text: Acting Director, Advance Pricing Agreement Program
label: BODY

text: Background
label: HH1

text: Internal Revenue Code (IRC) § 482 provides that the Secretary may distribute, apportion, or
label: BODY

text: allocate gross income, deductions, credits, or allowances between or among two or more
label: BODY

text: commonly controlled businesses if necessary to reflect clearly the income of such businesses.
label: BODY

text: Under the regulations, the standard to be applied in determining the true taxable income of a
label: BODY

text: controlled business is that of a business dealing at arm’s length with an unrelated business. The
label: BODY

text: arm’s length standard also has been adopted by the international community and is incorporated
label: BODY

text: into the transfer pricing guidelines issued by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and
label: BODY

text: Development (OECD).  OECD, TRANSFER PRICING GUIDELINES FOR MULTINATIONAL
label: BODY

text: ENTERPRISES AND TAX ADMINISTRATORS (1995).  Transfer pricing issues by their nature are
label: BODY

text: highly factual and have traditionally been one of the largest issues identified by the IRS in its
label: BODY

text: audits of multinational corporations.  The APA Program is designed to resolve actual or potential
label: BODY

text: transfer pricing disputes in a principled, cooperative manner, as an alternative to the traditional
label: BODY

text: examination process.  An APA is a binding contract between the IRS and a taxpayer by which
label: BODY

text: the IRS agrees not to seek a transfer pricing adjustment under IRC § 482 for a covered
label: BODY

text: transaction if the taxpayer files its tax return for a covered year consistent with the agreed
label: BODY

text: transfer pricing method (TPM).  In year 2002, the IRS and taxpayers executed 85 APAs and
label: BODY

text: amended 9 APAs.
label: BODY

text: Since 1991, with the issuance of Rev. Proc. 91-22, 1991-1 C.B. 526, the IRS has offered
label: BODY

text: taxpayers through the APA Program the opportunity to reach an agreement in advance of filing a
label: BODY

text: tax return on the appropriate TPM to be applied to related party transactions.  In 1996, the IRS
label: BODY

text: issued internal procedures for processing APA requests.  Chief Counsel Directives Manual
label: BODY

text: (CCDM), ¶¶ 42.10.10 – 42.10.16 (November 15, 1996).  Also in 1996, the IRS updated Rev.
label: BODY

text: Proc. 91-22 with the release of Rev. Proc. 96-53, 1996-2 C.B. 375.  The APA Program continues
label: BODY

text: to operate under the provisions of Rev. Proc. 96-53, which provides taxpayers with instructions
label: BODY

text: of how to apply for an APA, and what to expect in the processing of the case.  In addition, in
label: BODY

text: 1998, the IRS published Notice 98-65, 1998-2 C.B. 803, which set forth streamlined APA
label: BODY

text: procedures for Small Business Taxpayers (SBTs).  That Notice also expanded the availability of
label: BODY

text: the lowest APA user fee in an effort to attract taxpayers who may not have the resources to do
label: BODY

text: the sophisticated economic studies normally required in APA submissions.
label: BODY

text: Advance Pricing Agreements
label: BODY

text: An APA generally combines an agreement between a taxpayer and the IRS on an appropriate
label: BODY

text: TPM for the transactions at issue (Covered Transactions) with an agreement between the U.S.
label: BODY

text: and one or more foreign tax authorities (under the authority of the mutual agreement process of
label: BODY

text: our income tax treaties) that the TPM is correct. With such a “bilateral” APA, the taxpayer
label: BODY

text: ordinarily is assured that the income associated with the Covered Transactions will not be subject
label: BODY

text: to double taxation by the IRS and the foreign tax authority.  It is the policy of the United States,
label: BODY

text: as reflected in § 7 of Rev. Proc. 96-53 to encourage taxpayers that enter the APA program to
label: BODY

text: seek bilateral or multilateral APAs when competent authority procedures are available with
label: BODY

text: respect to the foreign country or countries involved.  However, the IRS may execute an APA
label: BODY

text: with a taxpayer without reaching a competent authority agreement (a “unilateral” APA).
label: BODY

text: A unilateral APA is an agreement between a taxpayer and the IRS establishing an approved TPM
label: BODY

text: for U.S. tax purposes.  A unilateral APA binds the taxpayer and the IRS, but obviously does not
label: BODY

text: prevent foreign tax administrations from taking different positions on the appropriate TPM for a
label: BODY

text: transaction.  As stated in Rev. Proc. 96-53, should a transaction covered by a unilateral APA be
label: BODY

text: subject to double taxation as the result of an adjustment by a foreign tax administration, the
label: BODY

text: taxpayer may seek relief by requesting that the U.S. Competent Authority consider initiating a
label: BODY

text: mutual agreement proceeding, provided there is an applicable income tax treaty in force with the
label: BODY

text: other country.
label: BODY

text: When a unilateral APA involves taxpayers operating in a country that is a treaty partner,
label: BODY

text: information relevant to the APA (including a copy of the APA and APA annual reports) may be
label: BODY

text: provided to the treaty partner under normal rules and principles governing the exchange of
label: BODY

text: information under income tax treaties.
label: BODY

text: The APA Program
label: BODY

text: APAs are negotiated with the taxpayer by an IRS team headed by an APA team leader.  As of
label: BODY

text: December 31, 2002, the APA program had 17 team leaders.  The team leader is responsible for
label: BODY

text: organizing the IRS APA team.  The IRS APA team arranges meetings with the taxpayer, secures
label: BODY

text: whatever information is necessary from the taxpayer to analyze the taxpayer’s related party
label: BODY

text: transactions and the available facts under the arm’s length standard of IRC § 482 and the
label: BODY

text: regulations thereunder (Treas. Reg.), and negotiates with the taxpayer.
label: BODY

text: The APA team generally includes an economist, an international examiner, LMSB field counsel,
label: BODY

text: and, in a bilateral case, a U.S. Competent Authority analyst who leads the discussions with the
label: BODY

text: treaty partner. The economist may be from the APA Program or the IRS field organization.  As
label: BODY

text: of December 31, 2002, the APA Program had 7 economists.  The APA team may also include an
label: BODY

text: LMSB International Technical Advisor, other LMSB exam personnel, and an Appeals officer.
label: BODY

text: The APA Process
label: BODY

text: The APA process is voluntary.  Taxpayers submit an application for an APA, together with a
label: BODY

text: user fee as set forth in Rev. Proc. 96-53.  The APA process can be broken into five phases:  (1)
label: BODY

text: application; (2) due diligence; (3) analysis; (4) discussion and agreement; and (5) drafting,
label: BODY

text: review, and execution.
label: BODY

text: Application
label: BODY

text: In many APA cases, the taxpayer’s application is preceded by a pre-file conference with the APA
label: BODY

text: staff in which the taxpayer can solicit the informal views of the APA Program.  Pre-file
label: BODY

text: conferences can occur on an anonymous basis, although a taxpayer must disclose its identity
label: BODY

text: when it applies for an APA.  Taxpayers must file the appropriate user fee on or before the due
label: BODY

text: date of the tax return for the first taxable year that the taxpayer proposes to be covered by the
label: BODY

text: APA.  Many taxpayers file a user fee first and then follow up with a full application later.  The
label: BODY

text: procedures for pre-file conferences, user fees, and delayed applications can be found in Rev.
label: BODY

text: The APA application can be a relatively modest document for a small business taxpayer.  Notice
label: BODY

text: 98-65 describes the special APA procedures for small businesses.  For most taxpayers, however,
label: BODY

text: the APA application is a substantial document filling several binders. The APA Program makes
label: BODY

text: every effort to reach agreement on the basis of the information provided in the taxpayer's
label: BODY

text: application.
label: BODY

text: The application is assigned to an APA team leader who is responsible for the case.  The APA
label: BODY

text: team leader’s first responsibility is to organize the APA team.  This involves contacting the
label: BODY

text: appropriate LMSB International Territory Manager to secure the assignment of an international
label: BODY

text: examiner to the APA case and the LMSB Counsel’s office to secure a field counsel lawyer.   In a
label: BODY

text: bilateral case, the U.S. Competent Authority will assign a U.S. Competent Authority analyst to
label: BODY

text: the team.   In a large APA case, the international examiner may invite his or her manager and
label: BODY

text: other LMSB personnel familiar with the taxpayer to join the team.  When the APA may affect
label: BODY

text: taxable years in Appeals, the appropriate appellate conferee will be invited to join the team.  In
label: BODY

text: all cases, the team leader contacts the Manager, LMSB International Technical Advisors, to
label: BODY

text: determine whether to include a technical advisor on the team.  The IRS APA team will generally
label: BODY

text: include a technical advisor if the APA request concerns cost-sharing, intangibles or services. The
label: BODY

text: APA team leader then distributes copies of the APA application to all team members and sets up
label: BODY

text: an opening conference with the taxpayer.  The APA office strives to hold this opening
label: BODY

text: conference within 45 days of the assignment of the case to a team leader.  At the opening
label: BODY

text: conference, the APA team leader proposes a case plan designed to complete the recommended
label: BODY

text: U.S. negotiating position for a bilateral APA within 9 months from the date the full application
label: BODY

text: was filed and to complete a unilateral APA within 12 months from the application date.  In 2002,
label: BODY

text: the median for completing negotiating positions was 12.0 months (average 13.7), and the median
label: BODY

text: for completing unilateral APAs was 15.9 months (average 20.2).
label: BODY

text: Due Diligence
label: BODY

text: The APA team must satisfy itself that the relevant facts submitted by the taxpayer are complete
label: BODY

text: and accurate.  This due diligence aspect of the APA is vital to the process.  It is because of this
label: BODY

text: due diligence that the IRS can reach advance agreements with taxpayers in the highly factual
label: BODY

text: setting of transfer pricing.  Due diligence can proceed in a number of ways.  Typically, the
label: BODY

text: taxpayer and the APA team will agree to dates for future meetings during the opening
label: BODY

text: conference. In advance of the opening conference, the APA team leader will submit a list of
label: BODY

text: questions to the taxpayer for discussion. The opening conference may result in a second set of
label: BODY

text: questions.  These questions are developed by the APA team and provided to the taxpayer through
label: BODY

text: the APA team leader.  It is important to note that this due diligence is not an audit and is focused
label: BODY

text: on the transfer pricing issues associated with the transactions in the taxpayer’s application, or
label: BODY

text: such other transactions that the taxpayer and the IRS may agree to add.
label: BODY

text: Analysis
label: BODY

text: A significant part of the analytical work associated with an APA is done typically by the APA or
label: BODY

text: IRS field economist assigned to the case.  The analysis may result in the need for additional
label: BODY

text: information.  Once the IRS APA team has completed its due diligence and analysis, it begins
label: BODY

text: negotiations with the taxpayer over the various aspects of the APA including the selection of
label: BODY

text: comparable transactions, asset intensity and other adjustments, the TPM, which transactions to
label: BODY

text: cover, the appropriate critical assumptions, the APA term, and other key issues.  The APA team
label: BODY

text: leader will discuss particularly difficult issues with his or her managers, but generally the APA
label: BODY

text: team leader is empowered to negotiate the APA.
label: BODY

text: Discussion and Agreement
label: BODY

text: This phase differs for bilateral and unilateral cases.  In a bilateral case, the discussions proceed in
label: BODY

text: two parts and involve two IRS offices -- the APA Program and the U.S. Competent Authority.
label: BODY

text: In the first part, the APA team will attempt to reach a consensus with the taxpayer regarding the
label: BODY

text: recommended position that the U.S. Competent Authority should take in negotiations with its
label: BODY

text: treaty partner.  This recommended U.S. negotiating position is a paper drafted by the APA team
label: BODY

text: leader and signed by the APA Director that provides the APA Program’s view of the best TPM
label: BODY

text: for the covered transaction, taking into account IRC § 482 and the regulations thereunder, the
label: BODY

text: relevant tax treaty, and the U.S. Competent Authority’s experience with the treaty partner.
label: BODY

text: The experience of the APA office and the U.S. Competent Authority is that APA negotiations
label: BODY

text: are likely to proceed more rapidly with a foreign competent authority if the taxpayer fully
label: BODY

text: supports the U.S. negotiating position.  Consequently, the APA Office works together with the
label: BODY

text: taxpayer in developing the recommended U.S. negotiating position.  On occasion, the APA team
label: BODY

text: will agree to disagree with a taxpayer.  In these cases, the APA office will send a recommended
label: BODY

text: U.S. negotiating position to the U.S. Competent Authority that includes elements with which the
label: BODY

text: taxpayer does not agree.  This disagreement is noted in the paper.  The APA team leader also
label: BODY

text: solicits the views of the field members of the APA team, and, in the vast majority of APA cases,
label: BODY

text: the international examiner, LMSB field counsel, and other IRS field team members concur in the
label: BODY

text: position prepared by the APA team leader.
label: BODY

text: Once the APA Program completes the recommended U.S. negotiating position, the APA process
label: BODY

text: shifts from the APA Program to the U.S. Competent Authority.  The U.S. Competent Authority
label: BODY

text: analyst assigned to the APA takes the recommended U.S. negotiating position and prepares the
label: BODY

text: final U.S. negotiating position, which is then transmitted to the foreign competent authority.  The
label: BODY

text: negotiations with the foreign competent authority are conducted by the U.S. Competent
label: BODY

text: Authority analyst, most often in face-to-face negotiating sessions conducted periodically
label: BODY

text: throughout the year.  At the request of the U.S. Competent Authority analyst, the APA team
label: BODY

text: leader may continue to assist the negotiations.
label: BODY

text: In unilateral APA cases, the discussions proceed solely between the APA Program and the
label: BODY

text: taxpayer.  In a unilateral case, the taxpayer and the APA Program must reach agreement to
label: BODY

text: conclude an APA.  Like the bilateral cases, the APA team leader almost always will achieve a
label: BODY

text: consensus with the IRS field personnel assigned to the APA team regarding the final APA.  The
label: BODY

text: APA Program has a procedure in which the IRS field personnel are solicited formally for their
label: BODY

text: concurrence in the final APA.  This concurrence, or any items in disagreement, is noted in a
label: BODY

text: cover memorandum prepared by the APA team leader that accompanies the final APA sent
label: BODY

text: forward for review and execution.
label: BODY

text: Drafting, Review, and Execution
label: BODY

text: Once the IRS and the taxpayer reach agreement, the drafting of the final APA generally takes
label: BODY

text: little time because the APA Program has developed standard language that is incorporated into
label: BODY

text: every APA.  The current version of this language is found in Attachment A.  APAs are reviewed
label: BODY

text: by the Branch Chief and the APA Director.  In addition, the team leader prepares a summary
label: BODY

text: memorandum for the Associate Chief Counsel (International) (ACC(I)).  On March 1, 2001, the
label: BODY

text: ACC(I) delegated to the APA Director the authority to execute APAs on behalf of the IRS.  See
label: BODY

text: Chief Counsel Notice CC-2001-016.  The APA is executed for the taxpayer by an appropriate
label: BODY

text: corporate officer.
label: BODY

text: Model APA at Attachment A
label: BODY

text: Attachment A contains the current version of the model APA language.  As part of its continuing
label: BODY

text: effort to improve its work product, the APA Program has revised the model language to reflect
label: BODY

text: the program’s collective experience with substantive and drafting issues.
label: BODY

text: The Current APA Office Structure, Composition, and Operation
label: HH1

text: In 2002, the APA Office consisted of four branches with Branches 1 and 3 staffed with APA
label: BODY

text: team leaders and Branch 2 staffed with economists and a paralegal.1  Branch 4, the APA West
label: BODY

text: Coast branch, opened an additional office in Laguna Niguel and moved its headquarters there.
label: BODY

text: Its staffing is indicated in the chart below.
label: BODY

text: Overall, the APA staff decreased from 38 to 34 as a result of attrition and transfers to other Chief
label: BODY

text: Counsel functions.  The number of APA team leaders decreased from 22 to 17, while the number
label: BODY

text: of economists remained constant at 7.  Despite the decrease in the number of APA team leaders,
label: BODY

text: the combination of the APA Program’s extensive training and smaller caseloads per APA team
label: BODY

text: leader increased productivity and the currency of the APA inventory.
label: BODY

text: APA Training
label: BODY

text: In 2002, the APA Office continued to emphasize training as a high priority, dedicating two half-
label: BODY

text: days each month to full staff training sessions.  These training sessions regarded APA-related
label: BODY

text: current developments, new APA office practices and procedures, and international tax law
label: BODY

text: issues.  Updated APA New Hire Training materials were published and provided to the APA
label: BODY

text: staff, and to the public through the APA internet site on the IRS Digital Daily (www.irs.gov).
label: BODY

text: Discussion
label: BODY

text: The vast majority of APAs have covered transactions that involve numerous business functions
label: BODY

text: and risks. For instance, with respect to functions, companies that manufacture products have
label: BODY

text: typically conducted research and development, engaged in product design and engineering,
label: BODY

text: manufactured the product, marketed and distributed the product, and performed support
label: BODY

text: functions such as legal, finance, and human resources services. Regarding risks, companies have
label: BODY

text: been subject to market risks, R&D risks, financial risks, credit and collection risks, product
label: BODY

text: liability risks, and general business risks. In the APA evaluation process a significant amount of
label: BODY

text: time and effort is devoted to understanding how the functions and risks are allocated amongst the
label: BODY

text: controlled group of companies that are party to the covered transactions.
label: BODY

text: In its APA submission, the taxpayer must provide a functional analysis. The functional analysis
label: BODY

text: identifies the economic activities performed, the assets employed, the economic costs incurred,
label: BODY

text: and the risks assumed by each of the controlled parties. The importance of the functional analysis
label: BODY

text: derives from the fact that economic theory posits that there is a positive relationship between risk
label: BODY

text: and expected return and that different functions provide different value and have different
label: BODY

text: opportunity costs associated with them. It is important that the functional analysis go beyond
label: BODY

text: simply categorizing the tested party as, say, a distributor. It should provide more specific
label: BODY

text: information since, in the example of distributors, not all distributors undertake similar functions
label: BODY

text: and risks.
label: BODY

text: Thus, the functional analysis is critical in determining the TPM (including the selection of
label: BODY

text: comparables). Although functional comparability is an essential factor in evaluating the
label: BODY

text: reliability of the TPM (including the selection of comparables), the APA evaluation process also
label: BODY

text: involves consideration of economic conditions such as the economic condition of the particular
label: BODY

text: industry.
label: BODY

text: In evaluating the functional analysis, the APA program considers contractual terms between the
label: BODY

text: controlled parties and the consistency of the conduct of the parties with respect to the allocation
label: BODY

text: of risk. In accord with the section 482 regulations, the APA program also gives consideration to
label: BODY

text: the ability of controlled parties to fund losses that might be expected to occur as the result of the
label: BODY

text: assumption of risk. Another relevant factor considered in evaluating the functional analysis is the
label: BODY

text: extent to which each controlled party exercises managerial or operational control over the
label: BODY

text: business activities that directly influence the amount of income or loss realized. The section 482
label: BODY

text: regulations posit that parties at arm's length will ordinarily bear a greater share of those risks
label: BODY

text: over which they have relatively more control.
label: BODY

text: Discussion
label: BODY

text: The TPMs used in APAs completed during Year 2002 were based on the section 482 regulations.
label: BODY

text: Under Treas. Reg. § 1.482-3, the arm’s length amount for controlled transfers of tangible
label: BODY

text: property may be determined using the Comparable Uncontrolled Price (CUP) method, the Resale
label: BODY

text: Price Method, the Cost Plus Method, the Comparable Profits Method (CPM), or the Profit Split
label: BODY

text: method.  Under Treas. Reg. § 1.482-4, the arm’s length amount for controlled transfers of
label: BODY

text: intangible property may be determined using the Comparable Uncontrolled Transaction (CUT)
label: BODY

text: method, CPM, or the Profit Split Method.  An “Unspecified Method” may be used for both
label: BODY

text: tangible and intangible property if it provides a more reliable result than the enumerated methods
label: BODY

text: under the best method rule of Treas. Reg. § 1.482-1(c).  For transfers involving the provision of
label: BODY

text: services, Treas. Reg. § 1.482-2(b) provides that services performed for the benefit of another
label: BODY

text: member of a controlled group should bear an arm’s length charge, either deemed to be equal to
label: BODY

text: the cost of providing the services (when non-integral) or which should be an amount that would
label: BODY

text: have been charged between independent parties.
label: BODY

text: In addition, Treas. Reg. § 1.482-2(a) provides rules concerning the proper treatment of loans or
label: BODY

text: advances, and Treas. Reg. § 1.482-7 provides rules for qualified cost sharing arrangements under
label: BODY

text: which the parties agree to share the costs of development of intangibles in proportion to their
label: BODY

text: shares of reasonably anticipated benefits.  APAs involving cost sharing arrangements generally
label: BODY

text: address both the method of allocating costs among the parties as well as determining the
label: BODY

text: appropriate amount of the “buy-in” payment due for the transfer of intangibles to the controlled
label: BODY

text: participants.
label: BODY

text: In reviewing the TPMs applicable to transfers of tangible and intangible property reflected in
label: BODY

text: Table 16, the majority of the APAs followed the specified methods.  However, there are several
label: BODY

text: distinguishing points that should be made.  The Regulations note that for transfers of tangible
label: BODY

text: property, the Comparable Uncontrolled Price (CUP) method will generally be the most direct
label: BODY

text: and reliable measure of an arm’s length price for the controlled transaction if sufficiently reliable
label: BODY

text: comparable transactions can be identified.  Treas. Reg. § 1.482-3(b)(2)(ii)(A).  It was the
label: BODY

text: experience of the APA Program in Year 2002 that in the cases that come into the APA Program,
label: BODY

text: sufficiently reliable CUP transactions are difficult to find.  In APAs executed in Year 2002, there
label: BODY

text: were five covered transactions that used the CUP method; three looked to published market data
label: BODY

text: and two used internal data on transactions between the taxpayer and unrelated parties.
label: BODY

text: Similar to the CUP method, for transfers of intangible property, the CUT method will generally
label: BODY

text: provide the most reliable measure of an arm’s length result if sufficiently reliable comparables
label: BODY

text: may be found.  Treas. Reg. § 1.482-4(c)(2)(ii).  It has generally been difficult to identify external
label: BODY

text: comparables, and APAs using the CUT method tend to rely on internal transactions between the
label: BODY

text: taxpayer and unrelated parties.  In Year 2002, there were eight covered transactions that utilized
label: BODY

text: the CUT TPM.
label: BODY

text: The Cost Plus Method (tangibles only) and Resale Price Method were applied in Year 2002 in
label: BODY

text: five and eight APAs respectively.  See Treas. Reg. § 1.482-3(c), (d).
label: BODY

text: The CPM is frequently applied in APAs.  This is because reliable public data on comparable
label: BODY

text: business activities of independent companies may be more readily available than potential CUP
label: BODY

text: data, and comparability of resources employed, functions, risks, and other relevant
label: BODY

text: considerations is more likely to exist than comparability of product.  The CPM also tends to be
label: BODY

text: less sensitive than other methods to differences in accounting practices between the tested party
label: BODY

text: and comparable companies, e.g., classification of expenses as cost of goods sold or operating
label: BODY

text: expenses.  Treas. Reg. § 1.482-3(c)(3)(iii)(B), and -3(d)(3)(iii)(B).  In addition, the degree of
label: BODY

text: functional comparability required to obtain a reliable result under the CPM is generally less than
label: BODY

text: required under the Resale Price or Cost Plus methods, because differences in functions
label: BODY

text: performed often are reflected in operating expenses, and thus taxpayers performing different
label: BODY

text: functions may have very different gross profit margins but earn similar levels of operating profit.
label: BODY

text: Table 16 reflects 35 uses of the CPM (with varying PLIs) in covered transactions involving
label: BODY

text: tangible or intangible property.  The CPM was also used in some APAs concurrently with other
label: BODY

text: methods.
label: BODY

text: The CPM has proven to be versatile in part because of the various PLIs that can be used in
label: BODY

text: connection with the method.  Reaching agreement on the appropriate PLI has been the subject of
label: BODY

text: much discussion in many of the cases, and it depends heavily on the facts and circumstances.
label: BODY

text: Some APAs have called for different PLIs to apply to different parts of the covered transactions
label: BODY

text: or with one PLI used as a check against the primary PLI.
label: BODY

text: The CPM also was used regularly with services as the covered transactions in APAs executed in
label: BODY

text: Year 2002.  There were a total of fifteen services covered transactions using the CPM method
label: BODY

text: with various PLIs according to the specific facts of the taxpayers involved.  Table 17 reflects the
label: BODY

text: methods used to determine the arm’s length results for APAs involving services transactions.
label: BODY

text: In Year 2002, there were fourteen APAs involving tangible or intangible property that used the
label: BODY

text: residual profit split, Treas. Reg. § 1.482-6(c)(3).  In residual profit split cases, routine
label: BODY

text: contributions by the controlled parties are allocated routine market returns, and the residual
label: BODY

text: income is allocated among the controlled taxpayers based upon the relative value of their
label: BODY

text: contributions of intangible property to the relevant business activity.
label: BODY

text: Discussion
label: BODY

text: APAs include critical assumptions upon which their respective TPMs depend.  A critical
label: BODY

text: assumption is any fact (whether or not within the control of the taxpayer) related to the taxpayer,
label: BODY

text: a third party, an industry, or business and economic conditions, the continued existence of which
label: BODY

text: is material to the taxpayer's proposed TPM.  Critical assumptions might include, for example, a
label: BODY

text: particular mode of conducting business operations, a particular corporate or business structure, or
label: BODY

text: a range of expected business volume.  Rev. Proc. 96-53, § 5.07. Failure to meet a critical
label: BODY

text: assumption may render an APA inappropriate or unworkable.
label: BODY

text: A critical assumption may change (and/or fail to materialize) due to uncontrollable changes in
label: BODY

text: economic circumstances, such as a fundamental and dramatic change in the economic conditions
label: BODY

text: of a particular industry.  In addition, a critical assumption may change (and/or fail to materialize)
label: BODY

text: due to a taxpayer's actions that are initiated for good faith business reasons, such as a change in
label: BODY

text: business strategy, mode of conducting operations, or the cessation or transfer of a business
label: BODY

text: segment or entity covered by the APA.
label: BODY

text: If a critical assumption has not been met, the APA may be revised by agreement of the parties.
label: BODY

text: If such agreement cannot be achieved, the APA may be canceled.  If a critical assumption has
label: BODY

text: not been met, it requires taxpayer's notice to and discussion with the Service, and, in the case of a
label: BODY

text: bilateral APA, competent authority consideration.  Rev. Proc. 96-53, § 11.07.
label: BODY

text: Discussion
label: BODY

text: At the core of most APAs are comparables.  The APA program works closely with taxpayers to
label: BODY

text: find the best and most reliable comparables for each covered transaction.  In some cases, CUPs
label: BODY

text: or CUTs can be identified.  In other cases, comparable business activities of independent
label: BODY

text: companies are utilized in applying the CPM or residual profit split methods.  Generally, in the
label: BODY

text: APA Program's experience since 1991, CUPs and CUTs have been most often derived from the
label: BODY

text: internal transactions of the taxpayer.
label: BODY

text: For profit-based methods in which comparable business activities or functions of independent
label: BODY

text: companies are sought, the APA Program typically has applied a three-part process.  First, a pool
label: BODY

text: of potential comparables has been identified through broad searches.  From this pool, companies
label: BODY

text: having transactions that are clearly not comparable to those of the tested party have been
label: BODY

text: eliminated through the use of quantitative and qualitative analyses, i.e., quantitative screens and
label: BODY

text: business descriptions.  Then, based on a review of available descriptive and financial data, a set
label: BODY

text: 14 The majority of these LIFO to FIFO inventory accounting adjustments regard business activities addressed by a
label: BODY

text: bilateral competent authority agreement that established streamlined resolution guidelines.
label: BODY

text: of comparable transactions or business activities of independent companies has been finalized.
label: BODY

text: The comparability of the finalized set has then been enhanced through the application of
label: BODY

text: adjustments.
label: BODY

text: Sources of Comparables
label: BODY

text: Comparables used in APAs can be U.S. or foreign.  This depends on the relevant market, the
label: BODY

text: type of transaction being evaluated, and the results of the functional and risk analyses.  In
label: BODY

text: general, comparables have been located by searching a variety of databases that provide data on
label: BODY

text: U.S. publicly traded companies and on a combination of public and private non-U.S. companies.
label: BODY

text: Table 19 shows the various databases and other sources used in selecting comparables for the
label: BODY

text: APAs executed in Year 2002.
label: BODY

text: Although comparables were most often identified from the databases cited in Table 19, in some
label: BODY

text: cases comparables were found from other sources, such as comparables derived internally from
label: BODY

text: taxpayer transactions with third parties.
label: BODY

text: Selecting Comparables
label: BODY

text: Initial pools of potential comparables generally are derived from the databases using a
label: BODY

text: combination of industry and keyword identifiers. Then, the pool is refined using a variety of
label: BODY

text: selection criteria specific to the transaction or business activity being tested and the TPM being
label: BODY

text: used.
label: BODY

text: The listed databases allow for searches by industrial classification, by keywords, or by both.
label: BODY

text: These searches can yield a number of companies whose business activities may or may not be
label: BODY

text: comparable to those of the entity being tested.  Therefore, comparables based solely on industry
label: BODY

text: classification or keyword searches are rarely used in APAs.  Instead, the pool of comparables is
label: BODY

text: examined closely, and companies are selected based on a combination of screens, business
label: BODY

text: descriptions, and other information found in the companies’ Annual Reports to shareholders and
label: BODY

text: filings with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC).
label: BODY

text: Business activities are required to meet certain basic comparability criteria to be considered
label: BODY

text: comparables.  Functions, risks, economic conditions, and the property (product or intangible) and
label: BODY

text: services associated with the transaction must be comparable.  Determining comparability can be
label: BODY

text: difficult – the goal has been to use comparability criteria restrictive enough to eliminate business
label: BODY

text: activities that are not comparable, but yet not so restrictive as to have no comparables remaining.
label: BODY

text: The APA Program normally has begun with relatively strict comparability criteria and then has
label: BODY

text: relaxed them slightly if necessary to derive a pool of reliable comparables.  A determination on
label: BODY

text: the appropriate size of the comparables set, as well as the business activities that comprise the
label: BODY

text: set, is highly fact specific and depends on the reliability of the results.
label: BODY

text: In addition, the APA Program, consistent with the section 482 regulations, generally has looked
label: BODY

text: at the results of comparables over a multi-year period.  Sometimes this has been three years, but
label: BODY

text: it has been more or less, depending on the circumstances of the controlled transaction.  Using a
label: BODY

text: shorter period might result in the inclusion of comparables in different stages of economic
label: BODY

text: development or use of atypical years of a comparable subject to cyclical fluctuations in business
label: BODY

text: conditions.
label: BODY

text: Many covered transactions have been tested with comparables that have been chosen using
label: BODY

text: additional criteria and/or screens. These include sales level criteria and tests for financial distress
label: BODY

text: and product comparability.  These common selection criteria and screens have been used to
label: BODY

text: increase the overall comparability of a group of companies and as a basis for further research.
label: BODY

text: The sales level screen, for example, has been used to remove companies that, due to their size,
label: BODY

text: might face fundamentally different economic conditions from those of the transaction or business
label: BODY

text: activities being tested.  In addition, APA analyses have incorporated selection criteria related to
label: BODY

text: removing companies experiencing "financial distress" due to concerns that companies in
label: BODY

text: financial distress often have experienced unusual circumstances that would render them not
label: BODY

text: comparable to the business activity being tested.  These criteria include:  an unfavorable auditor's
label: BODY

text: opinion, bankruptcy, and in certain circumstances, operating losses in a given number of years.
label: BODY

text: An additional important class of selection criteria is the development and ownership of
label: BODY

text: intangible property.  In some cases in which the business activity being tested is a manufacturer,
label: BODY

text: several criteria have been used to ensure, for example, that if the controlled entity does not own
label: BODY

text: significant manufacturing intangibles or conduct research and development (R&D), then neither
label: BODY

text: will the comparables.  These selection criteria have included determining the importance of
label: BODY

text: patents to a company or screening for R&D expenditures as a percentage of sales.  Again,
label: BODY

text: quantitative screens related to identifying comparables with significant intangible property
label: BODY

text: generally have been used in conjunction with an understanding of the comparable derived from
label: BODY

text: publicly available business information.
label: BODY

text: Selection criteria relating to asset comparability and operating expense comparability have also
label: BODY

text: been used at times.  A screen of property, plant, and equipment (PP&E) as a percentage of sales
label: BODY

text: or assets, combined with a reading of a company's SEC filings, has been used to help ensure that
label: BODY

text: distributors (generally lower PP&E) were not compared with manufacturers (generally higher
label: BODY

text: PP&E), regardless of their industry classification.  Similarly, a test involving the ratio of
label: BODY

text: operating expenses to sales has helped to determine whether a company undertakes a significant
label: BODY

text: marketing and distribution function.

text: Adjusting Comparables
label: BODY

text: After the comparables have been selected, the regulations require that "[i]f there are material
label: BODY

text: differences between the controlled and uncontrolled transactions, adjustments must be made if
label: BODY

text: the effect of such differences on prices or profits can be ascertained with sufficient accuracy to
label: BODY

text: improve the reliability of the results."  Treas. Reg. § 1.482-1(d)(2).  In almost all cases involving
label: BODY

text: income-statement-based PLIs, certain "asset intensity" or "balance sheet" adjustments for factors
label: BODY

text: that have generally agreed-upon effects on profits are calculated.  In addition, in specific cases,
label: BODY

text: additional adjustments are performed to improve reliability.
label: BODY

text: The most common balance sheet adjustments used in APAs are adjustments for differences in
label: BODY

text: accounts receivable, inventories, and accounts payable.  The APA Program generally has
label: BODY

text: required adjustments for receivables, inventory, and payables based on the principle that there is
label: BODY

text: an opportunity cost for holding assets.  For these assets it is generally assumed that the cost is a
label: BODY

text: short-term debt interest rate.
label: BODY

text: To compare the profits of two business activities with different relative levels of receivables,
label: BODY

text: inventory, or payables, the APA Program estimates the carrying costs of each item and adjusts
label: BODY

text: profits accordingly.  Although different formulas have been used in specific APA cases,
label: BODY

text: Attachment B presents one set of formulas used in many APAs.  Underlying these formulas are
label: BODY

text: the notions that (1) balance sheet items should be expressed as mid-year averages, (2) formulas
label: BODY

text: should try to avoid using data items that are being tested by the TPM (for example, if sales are
label: BODY

text: controlled, then the denominator of the balance sheet ratio should not be sales), (3) a short-term
label: BODY

text: interest rate should be used, and (4) an interest factor should recognize the average holding
label: BODY

text: period of the relevant asset.
label: BODY

text: The APA Program also requires that data be compared on a consistent accounting basis.  For
label: BODY

text: example, although financial statements may be prepared on a first-in first-out (FIFO) basis,
label: BODY

text: cross-company comparisons are less meaningful if one or more of the comparables use LIFO
label: BODY

text: inventory accounting methods.  This adjustment directly affects costs of goods sold and
label: BODY

text: inventories, and therefore affects both profitability measures and inventory adjustments.
label: BODY

text: Still important in some cases is the adjustment for differences in relative levels of PP&E between
label: BODY

text: a tested business activity and the comparables.  Ideally, comparables and the business activity
label: BODY

text: being tested will have fairly similar relative levels of PP&E, since major differences can be a
label: BODY

text: sign of fundamentally different functions and risks.  Typically, the PP&E adjustment is made
label: BODY

text: using a medium term interest rate.
label: BODY

text: Additional adjustments used less frequently include those for differences in other balance sheet
label: BODY

text: items, operating expenses, R&D, or currency risk.  Accounting adjustments, such as
label: BODY

text: reclassifying items from cost of goods sold to operating expenses, for example, are also made
label: BODY

text: when warranted to increase reliability.  Often, data is not available for both the controlled and
label: BODY

text: uncontrolled transactions in sufficient detail to allow for these types of adjustments.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Discussion
label: BODY

text: Treas. Reg. § 1.482-1(e)(1) states that sometimes a pricing method will yield "a single result that
label: BODY

text: is the most reliable measure of an arm's length result."  Sometimes, however, a method may yield
label: BODY

text: "a range of reliable results," called the "arm's length range."  A taxpayer whose results fall within
label: BODY

text: the arm's length range will not be subject to adjustment.
label: BODY

text: Under Treas. Reg. § 1.482-1(e)(2)(i), such a range is normally derived by considering a set of
label: BODY

text: more than one comparable uncontrolled transaction of similar comparability and reliability.  If
label: BODY

text: these comparables are of very high quality, as defined in the Regulations, then under Treas. Reg.
label: BODY

text: § 1.482-1(e)(2)(iii)(A), the arm's length range includes the results of all of the comparables (from
label: BODY

text: the least to the greatest).  However, the APA Program has only rarely identified cases meeting
label: BODY

text: the requirements for the full range.  If the comparables are of lesser quality, then under Treas.
label: BODY

text: Reg. § 1.482-1(e)(2)(iii)(B), "the reliability of the analysis must be increased, when it is possible
label: BODY

text: to do so, by adjusting the range through application of a valid statistical method to the results of
label: BODY

text: all of the uncontrolled comparables."  One such method, the "interquartile range," is ordinarily
label: BODY

text: acceptable, although a different statistical method "may be applied if it provides a more reliable
label: BODY

text: measure." The "interquartile range" is defined as, roughly, the range from the 25th to the 75th
label: BODY

text: percentile of the comparables' results. See Treas. Reg. § 1.482-1(e)(2)(iii)(C).  The interquartile
label: BODY

text: range was used 39 times in Year 2002.
label: BODY

text: Nineteen covered transactions reflected on Table 23 specified a single, specific result, or "point."
label: BODY

text: Ten of these covered transactions involved a CPM in which the taxpayer agreed to a specific
label: BODY

text: result.  Some APAs specify not a point or a range, instead using a "floor" that requires the tested
label: BODY

text: party's result be greater than or equal to some particular value.  Four APAs executed in Year
label: BODY

text: 2002 used a floor.
label: BODY

text: Some APAs look to a tested party’s results over a period of years (multi-year averaging) to
label: BODY

text: determine whether a taxpayer has complied with the APA.  In 2002, rolling multi-year averaging
label: BODY

text: was used for twelve covered transactions.  Eleven of those used three-year averages, and the
label: BODY

text: other one used a five-year average.  Cumulative multi-year averages were used for two covered
label: BODY

text: transactions.  Of those two transactions, one used a five-year average, and one used a seven-year
label: BODY

text: average.  Additionally, nine covered transactions used term averages.
label: BODY

text: Adjustments
label: BODY

text: Under Treas. Reg. § 1.482-1(e)(3), if a taxpayer's results fall outside the arm's length range, the
label: BODY

text: Service may adjust the result "to any point within the arm's length range."  Accordingly, an APA
label: BODY

text: may permit or require a taxpayer and its related parties to make an adjustment after the year's end
label: BODY

text: to put the year's results within the range, or at the point specified by the APA.  Similarly, to
label: BODY

text: enforce the terms of an APA, the Service may make such an adjustment.  When the APA
label: BODY

text: specifies a range, the adjustment is sometimes to the closest edge of the range, and sometimes to
label: BODY

text: another point such as the median of the interquartile range.  Depending on the facts of each case,
label: BODY

text: such automatic adjustments are not always permitted.  APAs may specify that in such a case
label: BODY

text: there will be a negotiation between the competent authorities involved to determine whether and
label: BODY

text: to what extent an adjustment should be made.  APAs may permit automatic adjustments unless
label: BODY

text: the result is far outside the range specified in the APA.  Thus APAs provide flexibility and
label: BODY

text: efficiency, permitting adjustments when normal business fluctuations and uncertainties push the
label: BODY

text: result somewhat outside the range.
label: BODY

text: In order to conform the taxpayer's books to these tax adjustments, the APA usually permits a
label: BODY

text: "compensating adjustment" as long as certain requirements are met.  Such compensating
label: BODY

text: adjustments may be paid between the related parties with no interest, and the amount transferred
label: BODY

text: will not be considered for purposes of penalties for failure to pay estimated tax.  See § 11.02
label: BODY

text: Efforts to Ensure Compliance with APAs
label: BODY

text: As described in Rev. Proc. 96-53, section 11, APA taxpayers are required to file annual reports
label: BODY

text: to demonstrate compliance with the terms and conditions of the APA.  The filing and review of
label: BODY

text: annual reports is a critical part of the APA process.  Through annual report review, the APA
label: BODY

text: program monitors taxpayer compliance with the APA on a contemporaneous basis.  Annual
label: BODY

text: report review provides current information on the success or problems associated with the
label: BODY

text: various TPMs adopted in the APA process.
label: BODY

text: All reports received by the APA Office are tracked by one designated APA team leader who also
label: BODY

text: has the primary responsibility for annual report review.  One of the economists also spends a
label: BODY

text: significant amount of time reviewing annual reports.  Other APA team leaders also assist in this
label: BODY

text: review, especially when the team leader who negotiated the case is available, since that person
label: BODY

text: will already be familiar with the relevant facts and terms of the agreement.  Once received by the
label: BODY

text: APA Office, the annual report is sent out to the district personnel with exam jurisdiction over the
label: BODY

text: taxpayer.
label: BODY

label: HH3

text: Definitions of Variables:
label: HH1

text: average accounts payable
label: BODY

text: AR =
label: BODY

text: average trade accounts receivable, net of allowance for bad debt
label: BODY

text: cogs =
label: BODY

text: cost of goods sold
label: BODY

text: INV =
label: BODY

text: average inventory, stated on FIFO basis
label: BODY

text: opex =
label: BODY

text: operating expenses (general, sales, administrative, and depreciation expenses)
label: BODY

text: PPE =
label: BODY

text: property, plant, and equipment, net of accumulated depreciation
label: BODY

text: sales =
label: BODY

text: net sales
label: BODY

text: total cost (cogs + opex, as defined above)
label: BODY

text: average accounts payable or trade accounts receivable holding period,
label: BODY

text: stated as a fraction of a year
label: BODY

text: interest rate
label: BODY

text: entity being tested
label: BODY

text: comparable
label: BODY

text: Equations:
label: HH1

text: If Cost of Goods Sold is controlled (generally, sales in denominator of PLI):
label: HH1

text: Receivables Adjustment (“RA”):
label: BODY

text: RA = {[(ARt / salest) x salesc] - ARc} x {i/[1+(i x hc)]}
label: BODY

text: Payables Adjustment (“PA”):
label: BODY

text: PA = {[(APt / salest) x salesc] - APc} x {i/[1+(i x hc)]}
label: BODY

text: Inventory Adjustment (“IA”):
label: BODY

text: IA = {[(INVt / salest) x salesc] - INVc } x i
label: BODY

text: PP&E Adjustment (“PPEA”):
label: BODY

text: PPEA = {[(PPEt / salest) x salesc] - PPEc} x i
label: BODY

text: If Sales are controlled (generally, costs in the denominator of PLI):18
label: HH1

text: Receivables Adjustment (“RA”):
label: BODY

text: RA =  {[(ARt / tct) x tcc] - ARc} x {i/[1+(i x hc)]}
label: BODY

text: Payables Adjustment (“PA”):
label: BODY

text: PA = {[(APt / tct) x tcc] - APc} x {i/[1+(i x hc)]}
label: BODY

text: Inventory Adjustment (“IA”):
label: BODY

text: IA = {[(INVt / tct) x tcc] - INVc } x i
label: BODY

text: PP&E Adjustment (“PPEA”):
label: BODY

text: PPEA = {[(PPEt / tct) x tcc] - PPEc} x i
label: BODY

text: Then Adjust Comparables as Follows:
label: HH1

text: adjusted salesc = salesc + RA
label: BODY

text: adjusted cogsc  = cogsc + PA - IA
label: BODY

text: adjusted opexc  = opexc - PPEA
label: BODY

text: 18 Depending on the specific facts, the equations below may use total costs (“tc”) or cost of goods sold (“cogs”).
label: BODY
